{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{About|intentional damage of art|unintentional damage|Accidental damage of art}} [[File:Cleveland Museum of Art - damaged Thinker.jpg|thumb|Vandalized cast of [[Auguste Rodin|Rodin's]] ''[[The Thinker]]'', [[Cleveland Museum of Art]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]], US]]
'''Vandalism of art''' is intentional damage of an artwork. The object, usually exhibited in public, becomes damaged as a result of the act, and remains in place right after the act. This may distinguish it from [[art destruction]] and [[iconoclasm]], where it may be wholly destroyed and removed, and [[art theft]], or [[Looted art|looting]].
Numerous acts of vandalism against art exhibits are known and some objects, such as ''[[Mona Lisa]]'', ''[[Night Watch (painting)|Night Watch]]'' and ''[[The Little Mermaid (statue)|The Little Mermaid]]'', have been intentionally damaged several times. Many vandals were diagnosed with a mental disorder and some, such as [[Hans-Joachim Bohlmann]], had a history of attacking artworks. A vast amount of damage consists of leaving a minor scratch, a stuck chewing gum, a pencil mark and so on, and usually escapes publicity.<ref>[[#Gamboni|Gamboni]], p. 191</ref> More visible acts of vandalism were premeditated, as the tool of destruction – a knife, paint, acid or hammer – was intentionally brought to the scene. In most cases, the artworks were restored. Restorations were costly and time-consuming and in many cases were followed by shielding the artwork from future attacks.
== History of the term ==
The term ''vandalisme'' was coined in 1794 by [[Henri Grégoire]], bishop of [[Blois]], to describe the destruction of artwork following the [[French Revolution]]. The term originated from the invasion of Rome in 455 by the [[Germanic peoples|East Germanic tribe]] of [[Vandals]], which resulted in destruction of numerous artworks, and was quickly adopted across Europe.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Merrills |first1=Andy |last2=Miles |first2=Richard |title=The Vandals |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |year=2010 |isbn=978-1-4051-6068-1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yTIHPoyMOFYC&printsec=frontcover|pages=9–10}}</ref>
== Repeated vandalism ==
=== Hans-Joachim Bohlmann ===
[[Hans-Joachim Bohlmann]] (1937–2009) was a German serial vandal. Between 1977 and 2006, he damaged over 50 paintings worth more than 270 million [[Deutsche Mark]]s (about 138 million euros) by [[Peter Paul Rubens|Rubens]], [[Rembrandt]], [[Albrecht Dürer|Dürer]] and other artists. Bohlmann had a [[personality disorder]] and was treated in various psychiatric hospitals since a young age. In most acts, he sprayed paintings with [[sulfuric acid]], targeting faces of the personages.<ref name=sp2>[http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-42008774.html Ich bin mein eigener Sklave]. ''Spiegel'', 1 October 2005 (in German).</ref> [[File:MonaLisaShield.jpg|thumb|upright|left|The setup of ''[[Mona Lisa]]'' exhibit in the [[Louvre]].]]
=== Mona Lisa ===
''[[Mona Lisa]]'' by [[Leonardo di ser Piero da Vinci|Leonardo da Vinci]] has long been attracting vandals and is currently one of the best-protected artworks. In 1956, the lower part of the painting was severely damaged when a vandal doused the painting with acid while it was on display at a museum in Montauban, France.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/magazine/5392000.stm|title=Faces of the week|work=BBC|date=29 September 2006}}</ref> On 30 December of the same year, a young Bolivian named Ugo Ungaza Villegas threw a rock at the painting; this resulted in the loss of a speck of pigment near the left elbow, which was later painted over.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20140328010816/http://www.monalisamania.com/faq.htm Mona FAQ]. Mona Lisa Mania</ref>
The use of [[bulletproof glass]] has shielded the Mona Lisa from more recent attacks. In April 1974, a handicapped woman, upset by the museum's policy for the disabled, sprayed red paint at the painting while it was on display at the [[Tokyo National Museum]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GgwUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CIsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2980,1609749|title=Mona Lisa sprayed|work=[[The Free-Lance Star]]|date=20 April 1974}}</ref> On 2 August 2009, a Russian woman, distraught over being denied French citizenship, threw a [[terracotta]] mug or teacup, purchased at the museum, at the painting in the Louvre; the vessel shattered against the glass enclosure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-08/12/content_11868974.htm|title=Mona Lisa attacked by Russian woman|work=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|date=12 August 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://newsok.com/russian-tourist-hurls-mug-at-mona-lisa-in-louvre/article/feed/66265|title=Russian tourist hurls mug at Mona Lisa in Louvre|agency=Associated Press|date=11 August 2009}}</ref> In both cases, the painting was undamaged.
=== Night Watch === [[File:Vandalized Night Watch 1975-09-16c.jpg|260px|thumb|Rembrandt's ''[[Night Watch (painting)|Night Watch]]'' after being cut by William de Rijk in September 1975]] Rembrandt's ''[[Night Watch (painting)|Night Watch]]'' (1642) is one of the most popular paintings at the [[Rijksmuseum]] in Amsterdam. It is viewed by about 4,000 to 5,000 visitors daily with its value estimated at $925,000 in the 1970s. The painting was vandalized on several occasions. On 13 January 1911, an unemployed navy cook tried to cut it with a knife, but could not cut through the thick varnish on the painting.<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9801E1DB1331E233A25757C1A9679C946096D6CF Slashes famous picture.; Discharged Naval Cook Mutilate Master's "Night Watch" at Amsterdam], ''New York Times'', 14 January 1911.</ref><ref name=t1>[http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1956922_1956921_1956951,00.html Rembrandt's Night Watch], ''Time'', 26 January 2010.</ref> In 1975, William de Rijk, an unemployed school teacher, cut dozens of zigzag lines in the painting with a knife before he was wrestled by the guards. The day before, de Rijk had been turned away from the museum because he arrived after closing time. After the event, he was identified with a mental disorder; he was sent to a psychiatric hospital and committed suicide there on 21 April 1976. It took six months to restore the painting, and traces of the cuts still remain.<ref name=t1/><ref name=c1978/><ref>Goss, Steven (Summer 2001) [http://www.cabinetmagazine.org/issues/3/toolsofartvandalism.php A Partial Guide to the Tools of Art Vandalism], ''Cabinet Magazine''.</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SM87KqxAuO8C&pg=PA114|page=114|title=Un iconoclasme moderne: théorie et pratiques contemporaines du vandalisme artistique|author=Gamboni, Dario |publisher=Editions d'En bas|year=1983|isbn=2-8290-0051-X}}</ref> In 1990, a man threw acid on the painting. The guards managed to quickly dilute it with water so that it penetrated only the varnish layer, and the painting was restored again.<ref name=t1/><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20160303225158/http://www.artcrimes.net/night-watch The Night Watch]. ''Art Crimes''.</ref>
=== The Little Mermaid === [[File:Little mermaid examined.jpg|260px|thumb|Police technicians examine the damage to [[The Little Mermaid (statue)|The Little Mermaid]] after it was blasted off its base on 10 September 2003.]]
''[[The Little Mermaid (statue)|The Little Mermaid]]'' is a statue of the mermaid from the [[The Little Mermaid|fairy tale of the same name]] by [[Hans Christian Andersen]]. The statue is located in the harbor of [[Copenhagen]] and is an icon and a major [[tourist attraction]] of the city. The statue has been damaged and defaced so many times since the mid-1950s that in 2007, Copenhagen officials announced that the statue may be moved further out in the harbor to avoid further vandalism and to prevent tourists from climbing onto it.
The main focus of vandalism for the statue has been [[decapitation]]. On 24 April 1964, the statue's head was sawn off and stolen by politically oriented artists of the [[Situationist International|Situationist]] movement. The head was never recovered and a new head was produced and attached to the statue.<ref name=m3/> On 6 January 1998, the statue was decapitated again;<ref name=m1/><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/45721.stm|date=8 January 1998 | work=BBC News | title=Feminists claim responsibility for statue attack}}</ref> the culprits were never found, but the head was returned anonymously to a nearby TV station, and re-attached on 4 February.
On the night of 10 September 2003, the statue was knocked off its base with explosives and later found in the harbor's waters. Holes were blasted in the mermaid's wrist and knee.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3103906.stm Little Mermaid's unexpected swim], BBC News, 12 September 2003</ref>
Paint has been poured on the statue several times, including one episode in 1963 and two in March and May 2007. On 8 March 2006, green paint was poured over the statue and a [[dildo]] was attached to its hand.<ref name=m3>[http://www.spiegel.de/reise/europa/0,1518,druck-572601,00.html Alter schützt Meerjungfrau nicht vor Rabauken (Age does not protect against Mermaid bullies)]. ''Spiegel'', 17 August 2008 (in German).</ref><ref name=m1>[http://jp.dk/indland/kbh/article1027279.ece Den Lille Havfrue reddet fra gramsende turister]. jp.dk. 1 August 2007. (in Danish)</ref>
== Acid and paint == {{see also|Hans-Joachim Bohlmann}} In 1880, exhibits of the Russian painter [[Vasily Vereshchagin]] in [[Vienna]] caused the opposition of the Catholic Church, which culminated in an attack on two paintings, ''Holy family'' ({{lang-ru|Святое семейство}}) and ''Resurrection'' ({{lang-ru|Воскресение Христово}}). A monk splashed enough acid on the paintings to virtually destroy them.<ref>[http://www.centre.smr.ru/win/artists/veresh/biogr_veresh.htm Peaceful painter]. centre.smr.ru (in Russian)</ref>
In 1974, [[Tony Shafrazi]] wrote "KILL LIES ALL" with red spray paint over the work ''[[Guernica (painting)|Guernica]]'' by [[Pablo Picasso]]. Shafrazi was ostensibly protesting [[Richard Nixon]]'s pardon of [[William Calley]] for the latter's actions during the [[My Lai massacre]]. The paint was removed with relative ease from the varnished surface.<ref>Hoberman, J. (13 December 2004) [https://web.archive.org/web/20050301174151/http://www.thenation.com/doc.mhtml?i=20041213&s=hoberman&c=1 "Pop and Circumstance"]. ''[[The Nation (U.S. periodical)|The Nation]]'', pp. 22–26.</ref>
On 15 June 1985, Rembrandt's 17th-century painting ''[[Danaë (Rembrandt painting)|Danaë]]'' was attacked in the [[Hermitage Museum]] in Russia. A man, later judged insane, first threw [[sulfuric acid]] on the canvas and then cut it twice with a knife. The entire central part of the composition was virtually destroyed.<ref name="Sluijter">{{Cite book |last=Sluijter |first=Eric Jan |authorlink= |title=Rembrandt and the Female Nude |publisher=Amsterdam University Press |year=2006 |page=221 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8FFH0vMv3DYC&printsec=frontcover|isbn=978-90-5356-837-8}}</ref> The restoration took 12 years, between 1985 and 1997; since then, the painting has been protected with an armored glass.<ref>Tylyakova, A. (1 November 1997) [https://web.archive.org/web/20120401143628/http://zn.ua/CULTURE/vozvraschenie_shedevra_rembrandta-9061.html ВОЗВРАЩЕНИЕ ШЕДЕВРА РЕМБРАНДТА] (Return of the Rembrandt's masterpiece). ''Зеркало недели'' #44, zn.ua</ref>
In 1997, [[Alexander Brener]] painted a green dollar sign on [[Kazimir Malevich]]'s painting [[:File:Suprematist Composition - Kazimir Malevich.jpg|''Suprematisme'']]. The painting was restored and Brener was sentenced to 5 months in prison. During the court case, he said in his defense:<ref>Battersby, Matilda (8 October 2012) [https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/features/art-attacks-from-vomiting-on-mondrian-to-elbowing-a-picasso-1879312.html?action=Popup&ino=10 Art attacks: From pissing in Duchamp's 'Fountain' to defacing a Rothko]. ''Independent.co.uk''.</ref> {{quote|The cross is a symbol of suffering, the dollar sign a symbol of trade and merchandise ... What I did was not against the painting. I view my act as a dialogue with Malewitz.}}
In 2012, Uriel Landeros spray painted a bull and wrote "Conquista" with black spray paint over the work ''[[Woman in a Red Armchair]]'' by Pablo Picasso. He was charged with felony graffiti and [[criminal mischief]] and sentenced to two years in prison.
In 2017, a [[2017 Paris machete attack|terror suspect attacked guards of the Louvre museum with machetes]] and was found carrying "bombs of aerosol paint" intended to "disfigure the masterpieces of the museum."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Emilie Blachère|title=Attack at the Louvre: the tourist was a terrorist|url=http://www.parismatch.com/Actu/Societe/Attaque-au-Louvre-le-touriste-etait-un-terroriste-1184744|accessdate=13 February 2017|work=Paris Match|date=13 February 2017|language=French|quote=Investigators found bombs of aerosol paint in his bag. No doubt to blot out the masterpieces of the museum.}}</ref>
== Knife == [[File:Ivan the Terrible & son - destroyed.jpg|thumb|upright|left|The part of [[Ivan the Terrible and His Son Ivan|''Ivan the Terrible and His Son Ivan'']] damaged in 1913]] [[File:Vandalized Rokeby Venus 1914.jpg|thumb|260px|Cuts in the ''Rokeby Venus'' made by [[Mary Richardson]] in 1914 using the meat cleaver shown in the top right corner]]
On 16 January 1913, a 29-year-old [[iconographer]] Abram Balashev attacked the painting [[Ivan the Terrible and His Son Ivan|''Ivan the Terrible and His Son Ivan'']] by [[Ilya Repin]] in the [[Tretyakov Gallery]] in Moscow. With three knife blows, he cut through the faces of both Ivans. Balashev was found mentally ill and restricted to a psychiatric hospital. The painting was restored by two leading Russian experts within a week; the work was greatly assisted by the availability of good-quality photographs of the painting.<ref>[http://rusk.ru/st.php?idar=25141 Scene of Blood, or how Ilya Repin killed Tsarevich Ivan. Part 6], ''Russian Herald'', 2007 (in Russian)</ref>
On 10 March 1914, militant suffragette [[Mary Richardson]] walked into the [[National Gallery]] of London and attacked [[Diego Velázquez]]'s painting ''[[Rokeby Venus]]'' with a [[meat cleaver]]. Her action was ostensibly provoked by the arrest of fellow suffragette [[Emmeline Pankhurst]] the previous day,<ref name="Davies">{{cite journal|author=Davies, Christie|url=http://www.newcriterion.com/articles.cfm/Vel-zquez-in-London-2567 |title=Velazquez in London|journal=New Criterion|volume= 25|issue= 5|date=January 2007|page=53}}</ref> although there had been earlier warnings of a planned attack on the collection. Richardson left seven slashes on the painting,<ref name="MacLaren, p. 125.">MacLaren, Neil; Braham, Allan (1970). ''The Spanish School, National Gallery Catalogues''. National Gallery, London, pp. 125–9. {{ISBN|0-947645-46-2}}</ref><ref name="Prater7">Prater, Andreas (2002). ''Venus at Her Mirror: Velázquez and the Art of Nude Painting''. Prestel, p. 7, {{ISBN|3-7913-2783-6}}</ref> all of which have been successfully repaired.<ref name="Davies"/> Richardson was sentenced to six months imprisonment, the maximum allowed for destruction of an artwork.<ref name="Nead">Nead, Lynda (1992). ''The Female Nude: Art, Obscenity, and Sexuality''. New York: Routledge, p. 2, {{ISBN|0415026776}}.</ref> In a statement to the [[Women's Social and Political Union]] shortly afterwards, Richardson explained, "I have tried to destroy the picture of the most beautiful woman in mythological history as a protest against the Government for destroying Mrs. Pankhurst, who is the most beautiful character in modern history".<ref name="Prater7"/> She added in a 1952 interview that she didn't like "the way men visitors gaped at it all day long".<ref name="Withford">Whitford, Frank (8 October 2006). "[http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/article661869.ece Still sexy after all these years]". ''The Sunday Times'', Retrieved on 12 March 2008.</ref>
[[File:Lorenzo Costa - De heilige familie - beschadigd 1969b.jpg|thumb|left|upright|The [[:File:Lorenzo Costa - De heilige familie.jpg|''Holy Family'']] by [[Lorenzo Costa]] at the Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam, with central cuts made by an unknown person in 1969]] In September 1969, unidentified persons left long scratches in five paintings at the [[Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam]], with most damage inflicted to the [[:File:Lorenzo Costa - De heilige familie.jpg|''Holy Family'']] by [[Lorenzo Costa]].<ref>5 schilderijen in Rijksmuseum zijn beschadigd door onbekenden A'dam: schilderij "De heilige Familie van Lorenzo Costa is het meest beschadigd. Dutch Nationaal Archief {{hdl|10648/ab7a20fc-d0b4-102d-bcf8-003048976d84}}</ref>
On 6 April 1978, a 31-year-old Dutch artist, disgruntled over the non-payment of his welfare by the Amsterdam authorities, made three 30–40 cm long cuts in the center of the painting ''[[:File:Vincent Willem van Gogh 084.jpg|La Berceuse]]'' by [[Vincent van Gogh]] at the Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam. A few days earlier, a 27-year-old Italian man slashed the painting ''[[The Adoration of the Golden Calf]]'' by [[Nicolas Poussin]] at the [[National Gallery]] in London.<ref name=c1978>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1917&dat=19780406&id=D-4wAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2eAFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1116,1817631 Van Gogh Painting Slashed]. Associated Press via Schenectady Gazette. 6 April 1978</ref>
In 1986, a man "wishing to take revenge on abstract art" cut with a knife the painting ''[[Who's Afraid of Red, Yellow and Blue]] III'' by [[Barnett Newman]]. The restoration took 5 years and cost $450,000. After serving time in prison, the offender slashed another Newman painting.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Who's Afraid of Corporate Culture: The Barnett Newman Controversy|author=Anderson-Reece, Erik |journal=The Journal of Aesthetics and Art Criticism|volume=51|issue=1|year=1993|pages=49–57|jstor=431970|doi=10.2307/431970}}</ref>
A rather unusual case, which might not qualify as vandalism, occurred in 1908. An exhibition was set up for May of that year with paintings by [[Claude Monet]], which had already been praised by critics and were estimated at $100,000 (1908 prices). Despite this, Monet decided that he was not satisfied with his work and in a sudden move destroyed all the paintings with a knife and a paint brush.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1956922_1956921_1956949,00.html Monet's Rage of Perfectionism], ''Time'', 26 January 2010.</ref>
== Smashing and shattering ==
On 7 February 1845, the [[Portland Vase]], a [[Roman glass|Roman]] [[cameo glass]] vase dated to between 5 and 25 BCE, was shattered by a drunken William Lloyd while on display in the [[British Museum]]. The vase was pieced together and underwent several further repairs, all not entirely successful. The vase's appearance became satisfactory only after its most recent restoration in 1987.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120202011228/https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/article_index/c/portland_vase_-_conservation.aspx The conservation history of the Portland Vase], British Museum.</ref>
On 14 September 1991, a "deranged" man attacked the statue ''[[David (Michelangelo)|David]]'' by [[Michelangelo]] with a hammer he had concealed under his jacket,<ref>"a man the police described as deranged broke part of a toe with a hammer, saying a 16th century Venetian painter's model ordered him to do so." Cowell, Alan (15 September 1991). [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CE3DC103CF936A2575AC0A967958260 "Michelangelo's David Is Damaged"]. ''New York Times''.</ref> damaging the toes of the left foot before being restrained.<ref>See [[#Gamboni|Gamboni]], p. 205 for picture</ref> The samples obtained from that incident helped scientists determine that the marble used was obtained from the Fantiscritti [[Quarry|quarries]] in [[Miseglia]], the central of three small valleys in [[Carrara]]. The statue was restored.<ref>Scigliano, Eric (August 2005) [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-135246927.html "Inglorious Restorations. Destroying Old Masterpieces in Order to Save Them."] ''Harper's Magazine'', pp. 61–68.</ref>
''[[Pietà (Michelangelo)|La Pietà]]'', another work by Michelangelo, is a 1499 example of [[Renaissance]] sculpture housed in [[St. Peter's Basilica]] in Vatican City. On 21 May 1972, mentally disturbed geologist [[Laszlo Toth]], aged 33, attacked the statue with a hammer while yelling "I am Jesus Christ!", chipping the Virgin Mary's left eyelid, neck, head, veil and left forearm; the forearm fell on the floor, causing the fingers to break. Most broken pieces were collected by the service people but some were taken by tourists. The sculpture was repaired and is now protected by bulletproof glass. Toth was not charged with a crime, but was found socially dangerous and confined for two years to a psychiatric institution in Italy.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1956922_1956921_1956949,00.html Michelangelo's Pietà], ''Time'', 26 January 2010.</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/notesandqueries/query/0,5753,-2565,00.html Whatever happened to Laszlo Toth, the man who smashed Michelangelo's Pieta in 1972?] ''Guardian''.</ref><ref>[[#Gamboni|Gamboni]], p. 202</ref>
On 17 February 2014, a local Floridian artist, Maximo Caminero, destroyed a coloured vase by the Chinese artist [[Ai Weiwei]] in protest at the [[Pérez Art Museum Miami]]'s lack of displays by local artists.<ref name=GuardFeb14>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/feb/17/florida-artist-smashes-1-million-vase-chinese-dissident-artist-ai-weiwei|title=Florida artist smashes $1m vase by Chinese dissident artist Ai Weiwei|date=17 February 2014|work=Associated Press via The Guardian}}</ref> The value of the vase was estimated at $1 million.<ref name=GuardFeb14/> Caminero was subsequently arrested and charged with criminal mischief.<ref name=GuardFeb14/>
On 26 May 2018, Repin's painting ''Ivan the Terrible and His Son Ivan'' was vandalized again. A 37-year-old drunken man grabbed a metal stand and repeatedly hit the painting, shattering its protection glass, seriously damaging the original wooden frame, and tearing the central part of the canvas. Fortunately, the most important details of the work, that is, heads and hands of the tzar and his son, were unharmed.<ref>[http://tass.ru/proisshestviya/5238382 В Третьяковке вандал нанес серьезные повреждения картине Репина "Иван Грозный". TASS (26 May 2018)</ref>
== Lipstick ==
In 1912, a young woman kissed the forehead, eyes and nose of a portrait by [[François Boucher]] in the Louvre. She reportedly wanted to draw attention to herself.<ref name=g192>[[#Gamboni|Gamboni]], p. 192</ref>
In 1977, 43-year-old Ruth van Herpen kissed a painting by [[Jo Baer]] at the Oxford Museum of Modern Art, claiming to try cheering up a "cold" painting. She was ordered by law to pay the restoration costs of $1,260.<ref name=g192/><ref>Harris, Shell (21 June 2008). [http://www.toptenz.net/top-10-famous-kisses.php Top 10 famous kisses]. ''Toptenz.net''.</ref>
On 19 July 2007, police arrested artist Rindy Sam after she kissed the all-white canvas of ''Phaedrus'' by [[Cy Twombly]], leaving a red lipstick mark. The artwork, which was worth an estimated $2,830,000, was on display at the Museum of Contemporary Art in [[Avignon]], France. First attempts to remove the mark using about 30 various chemicals were unsuccessful. Sam was tried in a court in Avignon for "voluntary degradation of a work of art". She defended herself by saying to the court: "It was just a kiss, a loving gesture. I kissed it without thinking; I thought the artist would understand... It was an artistic act provoked by the power of Art". In November 2007, Sam was convicted and ordered to pay €1,000 to the painting's owner, €500 to the Avignon gallery that showed it, and €1 to the painter.<ref>[http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/21211300 French court tries woman for kissing painting]. ''Associated press'' via msnbc.com. 9 October 2007.</ref><ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,311989,00.html Woman Who Kissed Painting With Red Lipstick Gets Community Service]. ''Associated Press'' via ''Foxnews'', 16 November 2007.</ref> In June 2009, she was ordered to pay €18,840 to the Yvon Lambert gallery.<ref>{{fr icon}} [http://artyparade.com/en/news-from-the-court/13 A very bling bling kiss – News From The Court – Arty Parade, or art in three dimensions]. Artyparade.com (28 November 2009). Retrieved on 2017-03-14.</ref><ref>{{fr}} [http://www.20minutes.fr/culture/329845-20090602-baiser-vole-rindy-sam-coute-18840-euros Le baiser volé de Rindy Sam lui coûte 18.840 euros]. 20minutes.fr (2 June 2009)</ref>
==Firearms== In July 1987, a man named Robert Cambridge entered the [[National Gallery]] in London with a sawn-off shotgun concealed under his coat. He then shot the drawing ''[[The Virgin and Child with St Anne and St John the Baptist]]'' by Leonardo da Vinci from a distance of about 2 meters (7 feet). The pellets did not penetrate the protective glass, but shattered it, and the splinters caused significant damage to the artwork. Cambridge told the police that he wanted to express his disgust with "political, social and economic conditions in Britain"; he was placed in a mental institution. The restoration of the drawing took more than a year to complete.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1988/11/08/arts/restoring-a-leonardo-drawing-that-was-hit-by-a-shotgun-blast.html Restoring a Leonardo Drawing That Was Hit by a Shotgun Blast], ''New York Times'', 8 November 1988.</ref>
==Other tools== In 1996 Canadian multi-media artist [[Jubal Brown]] vandalised [[Raoul Dufy]]'s ''Harbor at le Havre'' in the [[Art Gallery of Ontario]] in Toronto, and [[Piet Mondrian]]'s ''Composition With Red and Blue'' in the [[Museum of Modern Art]] in New York by deliberately vomiting primary colors on them.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/08/weekinreview/no-stomach-for-art.html|title=No Stomach for Art|date=8 December 1996|author=DePalma, Anthony |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
In January 1998, vandals poked holes in two paintings by [[Henri Matisse]], ''Pianist with Checkers Players'' (1924) and ''The Japanese Woman'' (1901), exhibited in the [[Capitoline Museums]]. The holes were mended in a few days.<ref>[http://www.museum-security.org/reports/00998.html Two Matisse paintings damaged in Rome exhibit]. museum-security.org quoting Reuters, 22 January 1998.</ref>
In January 2004 the Israeli ambassador to Sweden [[Zvi Mazel]] tried to destroy the artwork ''[[Snow White and The Madness of Truth]]'' by unplugging lights and throwing one of them into a pool causing a short circuit.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100605003020/http://www.dn.se/sthlm/ambassador-forstorde-konst-1.236382 "Ambassadör förstörde konst"]. ''Dagens Nyheter''. 17 January 2004.</ref>
On 24 February 2006, a 12-year-old boy stuck chewing gum to $1.5 million abstract painting ''The Bay'' by [[Helen Frankenthaler]], displayed at the [[Detroit Institute of Arts]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4767888.stm Boy sticks gum on $1.5m painting]. BBC News, 2 March 2006</ref> The museum's conservation lab successfully cleaned and restored the painting, which was put back on display in late June 2006.<ref name=Foxtheatre>Hodges, Michael H. (8 September 2003). [https://web.archive.org/web/20100109061438/http://apps.detnews.com/apps/history/index.php?id=215 Fox Theater's rebirth ushered in city's renewal]. Michigan History, ''The Detroit News''. Retrieved on 23 November 2007.</ref>
In 2007, the painting ''The Triumph of David'' by [[Ottavio Vannini]] (1640), exhibited at the [[Milwaukee Art Museum]], was attacked by a 21-year-old man with a history of mental illness. He pulled the painting off the wall, stomping on it several times. The man was reportedly disturbed by the image of Goliath's severed head.<ref name="vannini">{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/arts/visitor-attacks-valuable-painting/2007/04/05/1175366394722.html|title=Visitor attacks valuable painting – April 5, 2007| work=The Sydney Morning Herald | date=5 April 2007}}</ref>
In 2007, vandals broke into the [[Orsay Museum]] in Paris in the early morning, set off the alarm and damaged the painting ''Bridge at Argenteuil'' by Claude Monet. They left a {{Convert|10|cm|in|0|adj=on|sp=us}} tear in the middle, either with a hand blow or with a sharp object.<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-486280/Monet-masterpiece-slashed-drunks.html Monet masterpiece slashed by drunks], ''Daily Mail'', 8 October 2007</ref>
In 2012 a 49-year old man punched a large hole in [[Claude Monet]]'s ''[[Argenteuil Basin with a Single Sailboat]]'', valued at €10 million, while it was being displayed at the [[National Gallery of Ireland]]. Despite claiming to have a heart condition, a police investigation revealed that the act was deliberate and the man was jailed for six years.<ref name=ie>{{cite web |title=The moment vandal was caught punching Monet| publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/news/the-moment-vandal-was-caught-punching-monet-30805237.html|date= 7 December 2014 |accessdate= 15 August 2018}}</ref> After 18 months of restoration work, on 1 July 2014, the painting was re-hung in the gallery, behind protective glass.<ref name=RteRestore>{{cite web |title=Restored Monet returned to National Gallery| publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2014/0701/627635-monet-national-gallery/ |date= 1 July 2014 |accessdate= 18 January 2015}}</ref> The restoration saw 7% of the damaged area being lost, in a process that involved sewing microscopic threads back together.<ref name=BelfastRestore>{{cite web |title=Vandalised Monet work restored| publisher=[[Belfast Telegraph]]|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/republic-of-ireland/vandalised-monet-work-restored-30397673.html |date= 1 July 2014 |accessdate= 18 January 2015}}</ref>
